name: start_room
room_text: You are a young child caught out in the middle of suburbia, at night, alone. You come upon a large house. A REALLY large house, bigger than anything on either side of it, and certainly larger than anything you've ever seen before. It's made primarily out of bare plywood, some of it looking brand-new, but most looking molded and rotten. Suddenly, a strange force compels you to step forward. You attempt to resist it, but the urge is too strong! You slowly open the door and step inside. The door slams shut behind you! What do you do?

options.result_text: You try to force the door open, but it won't budge!
The door stays sturdy, not giving so much as a rattle.

The room around you, like the house outside, is made of barren plywood. The only light source is a large frosted-glass window situated in the front door. There are two large boxes in the right and leftmost corners in front of you. A big-brimmed hat and a long trench coat hang on a metal hook against the left wall. There are no other doors or windows.
You examine the room more closely. To your surprise, you find a small wooden trapdoor on the ceiling that you hadn't noticed before.

options.option_text: Pull a box over to reach the trapdoor

options.result_text: You attempt to smash the window with your fist. Great job! Now your hand hurts.
You attempt to smash the window again. The pain in your fist makes you want to cry.
The window again dismisses your hit. Your knuckles are cracked and bleeding.
The window has small red stains on its frosted glass. The cracks on your hand get larger.
The window has small red streaks on its frosted glass. The cracks on your hand get larger.
The almighty window is unamused. You only achieve further self harm.

Your hands seem to be moving on their own now. The only thing you can make out is blood. Blood everywhere. Blood on the window. Blood on the floor. Blood seeping into your shoes. Blood dripping down your clothes. As you get further in, it only gets more pronounced. Blood. Blood. Blood.

There is no going back now. Panic builds in your body as you attempt to stop, but the more panicked you get, the harder you pound. Broken bone sticks out of your knuckles and the tips of your fingers, pulling nerves and blood vessels up along with it. Chunks of your hands begin to fall on the floor. Slowly but surely, the gashes turn to missing fingers, blown holes, and pulverized bits of bone, all of which fall to the floor. You feel yourself become weaker, your face getting cold as blood leaks out of you like a fountain. You fall backward and land with the thud of wood. Your ears let out a high-pitched ring as you see and feel everything steadily fades to black.
Contrary to the barren plywood room, the door itself has been painted a muted white, with a darkened metallic handle. Both look brand new.
You sit on the floor and cry. Feels good.
